newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesia says will meet flight safety standards.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia says will meet flight safety standards.

text.p: Indonesia will comply fully with International Civil Aviation Authority (ICAO) safety standards to prevent a possible ban on Indonesian aircraft flying to the United States, state-owned Antara news agency said on Tuesday.
The news agency quoted Herry Bakti of the Air Transportation Department as saying Indonesia was working with America's Federal Aviation Authority (FAA) to implement ICAO standards.
"Our side and the FAA are now working out a plan for ICAO provisions on civil aviation safety in Indonesia," Bakti said.
Kompas newspaper reported last week that the FAA had given Indonesian national carrier Garuda until the end of the year to comply with international safety requirements.

If standards were not met, the paper reported, then not only would Garuda be banned from landing in the United States but U.S. carriers -- which for the moment do not operate in Indonesia -- could be prohibited from flying there in future.
American aviation officials, who spent three days in May inspecting Garuda planes that fly to Los Angeles, said they had found problems in aircraft servicing, which they did not disclose.
